talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 106 concerning the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) and the services of Mr A. Shand, QC and Mr Harvey in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal matter involving Whyalla Airlines, what was the total sum paid to each lawyer.

(2) With respect to the external legal services for each of the last five years for CASA, (a) what sums were paid to each lawyer in each year, (b) who were the lawyers and (c) in which legal proceedings were they involved.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority has advised that:
(1) The total paid to Mr Shand and Mr Harvey in relation to the AAT proceedings involving Whyalla was $66,450 exclusive of Goods and Services Tax.

(2) The legal costs incurred by CASA during the previous 5 years were incurred in relation to a variety of legal services, such as legal advice on regulatory, commercial, industrial and corporate issues and were not simply for “legal proceedings”. These costs were not paid to particular lawyers (except for individual counsel), but were paid to firms from whom advice and services were requested.
In relation to costs incurred for specific legal proceedings, CASA's records indicate that the following amounts were paid in relation to legal proceedings:

entry.para: South Pacific Sea Planes v. CASA
Royal Qld Aero Club v. CASA
Group Air Pty Ltd v. CASA
Sydney Harbor Sea Planes v. CASA
Ord Air v CASA & Saario v CASA
Lea v CASA and Hogan v CASA
Broadbent and Pacific Air v CASA
Royal Qld Aero Club v CASA
Ord Air- Wyndham Aviation v CASA
Royal Qld Aero Club v CASA

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Is it the case that the ATO's current plan, as per a draft GST ruling on prizes, will force radio stations to treat every contest and associated prize as a GST transaction.

(2) Is it also the case that all prizes, no matter how low in value, will have to be treated as payment for the services of the listeners and that this will include packets of chips, cans of soft drink, CD's, tickets to concerts and community events, and station promotional materials such as hats, stickers and t-shirts.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1)&(2) No. Radio stations will not have to pay GST on goods and services given away freely and unconditionally as part of a promotional activity.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 June 2002:

question.para: How many people with a disability are employed by the Minister's Department or agencies under the Minister's administration in the electoral division of Newcastle.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: From a recent Australian Taxation Office (ATO) staff census in the Newcastle region there are 11 employees with a disability.
The ATO is the only portfolio agency in the electoral division of Newcastle.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: Do Budget papers state that there will be no onshore asylum seeker processing; if so, why is there an ongoing program of beautification at Woomera.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The 2002-03 Portfolio Budget Statements state that “Based on current estimated arrival numbers and offshore processing capacity, it is expected that no additional unauthorised boat arrivals seeking asylum will be processed on the mainland”.
A landscaping program was completed at Woomera IRPC during the Financial Year 2001-02. There is no ongoing program of beautification.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 649)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Who will be detained at the Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre.
(2) What are the final figures for the Baxter centre, including both construction costs and projected running costs.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Baxter Centre is expected to be used primarily for unauthorised boat arrivals.
(2) Projected final construction costs are in the order of $44m. The running costs will depend on the level of utilisation of the facility and the outcome of the current tender process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: Were funds provided for the Singleton, Coonawarra and El Alamein Immigration Reception and Processing Centres during the period 1 July 2001 to February 2002, yet there were no detainees at those centres; If so, on what were the funds spent.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes. The funds were used to establish contingency detention facilities for unauthorised boat arrivals as announced by me on 23 August 2001. The main costs relate to fencing, the provision of utilities and the purchase and installation of demountable buildings.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Budget state that the Government has announced a policy for the offshore reception and processing of unauthorised boat arrivals seeking asylum, either at facilities on Australia's external territories which are excluded from the Migration zone or third countries; if so, why is money being spent on the Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre and why is money scheduled to be spent at Darwin and Brisbane.
(2) What was budgeted for the construction of the proposed Brisbane detention centre in budgets prior to the 2002-2003 Budget.
(3) What are the costs now budgeted and not disclosed in the 2002-2003 Budget.
(4) What, if any, discrepancy is there between the two sets of figures.
(5) Can his Department give a commitment that these centres will be used; if so, when.
(6) What is the future for Port Hedland.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
I announced the results of a Government review of mainland immigration detention facilities for unauthorised boat arrivals on 11 April 2002, including:
· The completion and commissioning of the Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre near Port Augusta;
· The closure of the facility at the Curtin RAAF base, which remains available as a contingency centre;
· The scaled down operation of the Woomera IRPC;
· A preferred site for a purpose-built immigration reception and processing centre in Darwin at the 11 Mile Antennae Farm; and
· The establishment of Australia's first permanent purpose designed and built immigration reception and processing facility on Christmas Island. (previously announced).

As part of the announcement of the review it was stated that the ongoing need for the development of an Immigration Reception and Processing Centre in Darwin would be revisited after the preferred site at the Department of Defence's 11 Mile Antennae Farm was decommissioned in 2003.

The Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre has greater amenity and security and will be more cost effective to run than contingency centres in the more remote areas. The commissioning of the Baxter facility allowed the closure of the Curtin IRPC.

The continued development of the Immigration Detention Centre in South East Queensland is required to take account of the need for detention facilities in that part of Australia as part of the Department's ongoing compliance program.
(2) No funding was provided for construction. Funding was provided on the basis of private sector development and leasing.
(3) Funding provided in the 2002-03 Budget is for the acquisition of land, as reported in the DIMIA 2002-03 Portfolio Budget Statements.
(4) None.
(5) The Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre has commenced operations. Brisbane will be used as soon as it is completed and commissioned.
(6) Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre remains part of the strategy for unauthorised boat arrivals.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: What are the industrial relations and human resource arrangements for Australians working on Nauru and Manus Island employed by UNHCR, IOM or any of the companies separately contracted to provide security, cleaning, or catering services.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: My Department does not employ people other than its own staff on Nauru and Manus. Employees of my Department are Australian Government employees under the Public Service Act and their employment conditions are governed by the provisions of respective Certified Agreements made under the Workplace Relations Act.

There are arrangements with the International Organization for Migration (IOM) and other agencies to provide a range of services on Nauru and Manus, but the arrangements which Australian employees might have with these organisations are subject to the human resource management policies and agreements of their employers.

My Department does not have details of employment arrangements and conditions provided by these agencies, but understands, for example, that Australians employed with IOM may fall under a range of different agreements according to international civil service standards for its staff. These agreements also need to conform with the industrial relations and employment legislative frameworks and conventions of the host countries involved.

subdebateinfo.title: Refugee Review Tribunal and the Migration Review Tribunal
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 657)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Migration Act require both the Refugee Review Tribunal and the Migration Review Tribunal to hand down decisions by making such decisions available to his Department and the applicant within two weeks.
(2) Are decisions taking longer than two weeks to hand down.
(3) What is the average time being taken to hand down decisions.
(4) On how many occasions in the last three years have decisions been handed down outside the two week period.
(5) What percentage of total decisions have been handed down outside the two week period in the last three years.
(6) What is the reason for the delays.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Sections 368B and 430B of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) require the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT) and the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) respectively to hand down decisions in all cases except where:
· the decision is given orally (MRT and RRT);
· the decision concerns a person in immigration detention (RRT);
· the decision concerns a person in immigration detention because of a decision to cancel or refuse to grant a bridging visa (MRT).

Neither the Act nor the Migration Regulations 1994 (the Regulations) require the decision to be handed down within a specified period. However, the Act provides that applicants and the Secretary of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) must be given a minimum period of notice of the handing down.

· In respect of MRT decisions, s.368A(3) of the Act requires the Tribunal to give the applicant and the Secretary of DIMIA written notice of the day, time and place at which the decision is to be handed down. The period of notice must be at least the prescribed period. The prescribed period for the MRT starts when the Tribunal gives the applicant notice of the day, time and place at which the decision is to be handed down, and ends at the end of 5 working days after the day on which the notice is received; or, if the applicant agrees in writing, at the end of a shorter period that is not less than 1 working day (r.4.27A). If the notice is posted to an address in Australia, the applicant is taken to have received the notice 7 working days after the date of the document (s.379C).

· In respect of RRT decisions, s.430A(3) of the Act requires the Tribunal to give the applicant and the Secretary of DIMIA written notice of the day, time and place at which the decision is to be handed down. The period of notice must be at least the prescribed period. The prescribed period for the RRT starts on the day on which the Tribunal gives the applicant the notice of the handing down, and ends at the end of 7 days after the day on which the notice is received (r.4.35E). If the notice is posted, the applicant is taken to have received the notice 7 working days after the date of the document (s.441C).

With regard to both the MRT and the RRT, where the applicant or the Secretary of DIMIA are not present at the handing down of the decision, the respective Tribunal must notify the applicant and the Secretary of its decision by giving each a copy of the written statement of the decision within 14 days after the day on which the decision is handed down (ss368B(6) and (7), MRT and ss430B(6) and (7), RRT, refer).
(2) to (6) As explained in the answer to part (1), there is no requirement that a decision must be handed down within 2 weeks.

For the RRT the average time taken to hand down decisions is 21 days from date of invitation to attend the handing down to the date of the handing down, while for the MRT decisions are handed down between 14 and 17 days after the date of the invitation to attend the handing down.

Where the applicant fails to attend the handing down of the decision, which in the RRT context is 79% of cases, and in the MRT context is approximately 69.5% of cases (as set out in the tables below), the written statement of the decision is provided to the applicant by the respective Tribunal within the 14 day period prescribed.

· In respect of the RRT, since the introduction of the handing down procedure, 79.4% of applicants have failed to attend the handing down, as set out in the following table. In those cases, the decision was mailed to the applicant within the 14 day statutory period.

· In respect of the MRT, since the introduction of the handing down procedure, approximately 69.5% of applicants have failed to attend the handing down, as set out in the following table. In those cases, the decision was mailed to the applicant within the 14 day statutory period.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) What are the details of the times, dates and reasons that the 80 air traffic movements an hour cap has been breached at Sydney Airport since the introduction of the cap.
(2) What action has been taken with regard to these breaches.
(3) Can he guarantee that there will be no further breaches of the cap; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Under the Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997, Airservices Australia is required to report to me on the extent of infringements (if any) of the maximum movement scheduling limit in each quarter. The movement cap reports covering exceedences of the 80 movement per hour cap since its introduction have been tabled in the House on 30 August 2000, 6 December 2000, 27 March 2001, 7 June 2001, 18 September 2001 and 14 March 2002. The reports and the supporting documents include dates, times and reasons for any exceedences of the 80 cap.

(2) The Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997 does not provide for any action to be taken for breaches of the cap itself. There is a separate regime under the Slot Management Scheme for aircraft that operate without a slot and aircraft that operate outside the allowed time limits that apply to an allocated slot.

(3) There can be no guarantee that there will be no further breaches of the cap. The Sydney Airport Slot Management Scheme is a planning mechanism that limits the number of allocated slots to 80. Operational factors such as unforeseen delays can cause aircraft movements to “bunch up” and the aircraft movement may not occur in the hour for which it has a slot but move into the next recording hour. This could mean that the actual number of movements in the next hour may exceed 80, even though the number of allocated slots is still 80 or less.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 401 in which he stated that the effects of the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) at Sydney Airport has been to significantly spread noise impacts with a consequent reduction in the overall numbers of properties within the noise contours that form the basis for eligibility for insulation under the Noise Amelioration Programme, what is his justification for that statement.
(2) Will he provide data on the number of noise affected households eligible for the Noise Amelioration Programme (a) prior to and (b) after, the introduction of LTOP.
(3) How can an increase in the spread over a large area of the Sydney Basin lead to a decrease in the number of properties eligible to participate in the Noise Amelioration Programme.
(4) What standard is used to measure noise in the mapping of noise contours to determine eligibility of a property to participate in the Noise Amelioration Programme.
(5) What is the scientific basis for the selection of the chosen standard and what are the merits of selecting that standard over the alternative standards available.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) See answer to question 2.
(2) (a) In excess of 4,500
(b) the eligible number is currently just over 4,300.

(3) Prior to the introduction of LTOP the burden of aircraft noise was essentially concentrated in areas in line with the parallel north-south runways. The effect of LTOP has been to spread this burden. As a consequence a smaller number of residential properties are subject to the high levels of aircraft noise exposure which would qualify them for insulation under the Noise Amelioration Programme.

(4) and (5) The Australian Noise Exposure Forecast System was established following a major socio-acoustic survey undertaken by the National Acoustic Laboratories. The ANEF system is considered more technically correct than other aircraft noise metrics and is therefore regarded as the most appropriate metric to use when determining eligibility for insulation against aircraft noise.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to his reply to parts (2) and (5) of question No. 403, can he indicate or give examples of how the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) might become aware of a change in the circumstances of the state of health of the former Senator, Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston, which might lead to the DPP reviewing the capacity of Dr Colston to stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if not, why not.
(2) Further to his reply to part (6) of question No. 403 and part (2) of question No. 555, what would need to happen for the DPP to deem it necessary to review the case of Dr Colston.
(3) When was the last time the DPP received a medical report concerning the state of health of Dr Colston.
(4) What did that report indicate in terms of the state of health of Dr Colston.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The DPP has indicated previously that it would, if necessary, review the matter. In July 2002 the DPP initiated a further review of the matter.
(3) 9 February 2001.
(4) That Dr Colston was unfit to stand trial.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Has he received correspondence and supporting documents from me concerning allegations made by Mr Dennis Brown JP that a Justice of the Family Court and Mr Peter Johnson interfered with a judgement of the Supreme Court of Queensland; if so, will he investigate the allegations.
(2) Will he obtain a transcript of the Supreme Court proceedings.
(3) Will he consider referring the matter to the Australian Federal Police for investigation when the transcript is obtained.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I have received a number of letters from Mr Windsor about allegations made by Mr Dennis Brown, the most recent dated 7 May 2002 to which my office responded.
I am advised that Mr Brown's allegations appear to relate to a decision made by the Supreme Court of Queensland in 1976.

In September 1999, Mr Windsor was advised that the material that Mr Brown forwarded to my Department in September 1997 was referred to the Australian Federal Police (`AFP') for their consideration of the issues raised by Mr Brown. The AFP decided to take no further action in the matter, noting that contributing factors in the decision were the lack of specific information provided to support Mr Brown's allegations and the length of time since the alleged incident occurred.

As Mr Windsor was advised, if Mr Brown has further evidence to support his allegations then my Department could make an assessment as to whether to forward such evidence on to the AFP for their further consideration of Mr Brown's allegations. I am advised by my Department that Mr Brown has not provided any further evidence and that the material supplied by Mr Windsor, with his letter of 7 May 2002, consists of Mr Brown's annotations on a speech given by Chief Justice Gleeson and does not constitute further evidence of Mr Brown's allegations.

It is not the role of the Attorney-General to investigate allegations of interference with court proceedings. This is properly the role of the AFP, which has in this instance declined to take the matter further.

(2) Any investigation of Mr Brown's allegations would be done on the basis of the evidence provided by Mr Brown. If Mr Brown considers that the transcript of the Supreme Court of Queensland proceedings in which he was involved might be of assistance in an investigation of his allegations, Mr Brown should obtain such a transcript.
(3) If Mr Brown is able to provide any further evidence, the material will be assessed by my Department and, if appropriate, forwarded on to the AFP for its consideration of Mr Brown's allegations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) In relation to the Sustainable Regions Programme (SRP), who are the members of the committees for all the eight sustainable regions and when were they appointed.
(2) What criteria were used to select the committee members.
(3) What selection process was undertaken in choosing the committee members.
(4) What skills, attributes and experience does each individual committee member bring to these positions.

(5) What rules apply to the operations of each committee including (a) how projects are identified, (b) how projects are chosen for funding, (c) how projects are announced, (d) how projects are monitored, (e) how projects are evaluated, (f) how the success of a project will be measured, (g) what protocols apply to committee meetings, (h) how many members of each committee must be in attendance at meetings involving funding allocation decisions and (i) what protocols are in place for replacement of committee members.
(6) When will selection of projects for funding in 2002-2003 be undertaken in each of the regions.
(7) When will projects for 2002-2003 be announced.
(8) Will he provide a copy of the standard contract for these projects
(9) What organisations are eligible to apply for SRP funding

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Members of the eight Sustainable Region Advisory Committees (SRACs) and
(b) their date of appointment are listed below:

para.inline: Far North East New South Wales

answer.para: SRAC appointed - 5 October 2001
Chair: Mr Geoff Provest.
Members: Mr Greg Redmond, Ms Robin Amos, Mr Chris Condon, Ms Lexie Hurford, and Councillor Ernie Bennett.
SRAC appointed - 5 October 2001
Mrs Julie O'Keefe appointed - 22 August 2002
Chair: Mr Bruce Hanrahan.
Members: Mr Ken Tagg, Councillor Geoff Corrigan and Mrs Julie O'Keefe (note Councillor Corrigan resigned from the Advisory Committee on 15 July 2002 and was replaced by Mrs O'Keefe).
SRAC appointed - 5 October 2001
Chair: Mr John Hutchinson.
Members: Ms Robyn Cooney and Dr Robert Haldane.
SRAC appointed - 10 December 2001
Chair: Mr Peter McDade.
Members: Councillor Mary Lyle, Councillor Anne Portess, Councillor Mick Borzi, Councillor Jim Chapman, and Professor Bob Beeton.
Date committee appointed - 21 December 2001
Mr Ian Trust appointed - 3 June 2002
Chair: Ms Cori Fong.
Members: Councillor Josie Farrer, Councillor Elsia Archer, Councillor Barbara Johnson, Councillor Kevin Fong, Mr Chris Kloss, Mr Ron Johnston, Mr Ian Trust, and Mr Jeff Gooding.
SRAC appointed - 18 February 2002
Chair: Mr Roger Jaensch.
Members: Mr Russell Paterson, Mr Bob Wilson, Ms Catherine Fernon, Ms Megan Cavanagh-Russell, Mr David Sales, Mr Ross Hine, Ms Judith Liauw, Mrs Mary Binks, and Mr David Reed.
Date committee appointed - 27 March 2002
Chair: Mr Peter Smith.
Members: Mr Tim Jackson, Mr Stephen Hains, Mr Kym Good, Mr Gerry Davies, and Mr Ron Watts.
SRAC appointed - 4 April 2002
Chair: Ms Diana Collins.
Members: Mr Robin Grundon, Ms Dot Hamilton, Councillor Ted Sorensen, Mr John Metelli, Mr Stephen Dixon, Mr Howard Leisemann, and Councillor Bill Trevor.
(2) Social, business, industry, environmental and cultural leaders and achievers in each sustainable region were selected for SRAC membership based on their knowledge and expertise.
(3) Prospective names were sought from the region based on (2) above and then sent to me for consideration.

(4) Each committee member was selected for their expertise within the region and the knowledge that they could bring to the role. Members were drawn from local government, local businesses, Area Consultative Committees, Indigenous communities and community organisations. All members are prominent in their region and were selected based on their past effective community involvement.

(5) (a) Projects are identified through an Expression of Interest (EoI) phase (which includes placing advertisements in local newspapers) and those that best meet the programme assessment criteria and the region's identified priorities are invited to submit a full application. (b) Each application is rigorously assessed by the SRAC and the Department of Transport and Regional Services against project assessment criteria with proponents needing to demonstrate the project will address one or more of the region's identified priorities. I make the final decision on whether a project receives funding. (c) Successful projects are announced in a variety of ways including launches, media releases and posting on web sites. (d) The Department of Transport and Regional Services and the Executive Officer in each region monitor projects and regularly report back to the SRAC on progress. (e and f) Projects are evaluated and their success measured using the reporting mechanisms in the funding agreement and the overall objectives of the programme. (g) The SRACs are governed by operating protocols published in the SRP guidelines and based on Australian National Audit Office best practice. These are listed below. (h) A quorum is required (see Operating Protocols). (i) Where a committee member resigns and needs to be replaced this is done in accordance with the criteria and processes outlined in (2) and (3) above.

para.inline: OPERATING AND GOVERNANCE ARRANGEMENTS FOR SUSTAINABLE REGIONS ADVISORY COMMITTEES

answer.para: The Sustainable Regions Advisory Committee shall advise the Minister for Transport and Regional Services on matters relating to the implementation and management of the Sustainable Regions Programme and its strategic direction for the region. This will include:
· In consultation with the community, determining the priorities of the region;
· Managing an EoI exercise;
· Providing direction to the Executive Officer;
· Assessing grant applications; and
· Making recommendations to the Minister on project funding.
The Advisory Committee shall be guided by the objectives and priorities of the Sustainable Regions Programme as it relates to the region.

· In undertaking the above, the Advisory Committee will; consider and provide advice on proposals, taking into account agreed selection criteria for projects, the programme guidelines and any departmental advice.
· Review and advise on programme documentation - such as guidelines and application forms - as required;
· Review and advise on programme direction; and

· Consider the Commonwealth's accountability requirements. The Commonwealth follows the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) accountability requirements. The ANAO Guidelines for the Administration of Grants are available from the ANAO Website at http://www.anao.gov.au/, under `Publications'.
The duties of the Chair are:

1. Lead the SRAC in the process of selecting and recommending projects for funding under the Sustainable Regions Programme, in accordance with the “Terms Of Reference - Sustainable Regions Advisory Committees” and the “Operating Protocols And Code Of Conduct - Sustainable Regions Advisory Committees”.
2. Act as spokesperson for the SRAC to the Minister, the public and the media.
3. Participate in the selection of an Executive Officer for the Sustainable Region.

4. Provide direction to the Executive Officer in accordance with a workplan agreed by the SRAC and the Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTARS) and in accordance with the Executive Officer's duties and responsibilities, which are:
· managing the Sustainable Regions Programme delivery in the region;
· provision of high level professional advice to the Advisory Committee to assist it in objectively assessing funding propositions from the community;
· provision of executive support to the Committee, including organising and preparing meetings, planning sessions and correspondence;
· initiating and managing partnership arrangements and coordinating activity between the Committee and government agencies, local communities and other organisations;
· initiating proposals with local community groups and assisting in the development and preparation of proposals;
· advising commercial entities and other regional stakeholders on the development of proposals to go before the Committee; and
· undertaking other duties as directed, including acting on behalf of the Committee.
5. Approve, in consultation with DOTARS, expenditure by the Executive Officer that is not included in a budget agreed by the SRAC and DOTARS.

para.inline: OPERATING PROTOCOLS AND CODE OF CONDUCT

answer.para: A majority of members shall form a quorum.
The Federal Department of Transport and Regional Services is to be an observer at meetings of the committee. A formal record/minutes must be taken and endorsed at the following meeting.

The committee will always try to reach a consensus but where a vote is taken at a meeting the outcome will be determined by the majority of members present. The majority and minority views will be conveyed to the Minister by the Department.
The Minister has approved funding for Advisory Committees to appoint an Executive Officer initially for a period of one year. The Executive Officer will assist the Chair and the Committee by:
· advising the Committee to assist in objectively analysing and assessing funding applications;
· providing administrative assistance and secretariat support to the Committee;
· liaising, negotiating and coordinating activity between the Committee and government departments and agencies, local communities, and other organisations;
· promoting the Sustainable Regions Programme and assisting local community groups to identify, develop and prepare proposals; and
· undertaking other duties at the direction of the Chair, acting on behalf of the Committee.
Any official communication with the media should be sanctioned by the Chairman and approved by the Minister's Office.
Members of the Committee must:
1.1 act with impartiality and integrity, conscientiousness and loyalty to the public interest;
1.2 ensure that the work of the Committee is not compromised or affected by any direct or indirect pecuniary or non-pecuniary interest;
1.3 ensure wherever possible that there is no public perception that the committee's work may be so compromised or affected;
1.4 act as an independent adviser rather than an advocate for any stakeholder organisation;
1.5 ensure the confidentiality of information dealt with by the Committee;
1.6 act in good faith for proper purposes without exceeding their powers; and
1.7 be frank and honest in their official dealings with each other.

2.1 With the exception of material referred to in paragraph 2.2, all information, whether written or not, dealt with by the Committee shall be treated as confidential unless agreed otherwise by a majority of the Committee.

2.2 Any member tabling a document may identify it as not being of a confidential nature, and seek the Committee's agreement to that status. However, Committee members should not use such information for purposes unrelated to the Committee's functions. The distribution of such information outside the membership of the Committee may be limited or restricted by agreement of the Committee.
2.3 Information available to members must not be used to obtain any advantage whether direct or indirect, for themselves or for any other person or body.
2.4 Confidential information available to members must be used only in ways which are consistent with the obligations of members to act impartially, with integrity and in the public interest.

2.5 Where confidential information is provided to a Committee member, care must be taken to ensure that the information is kept in secure storage, and that numbers of copies are kept to the minimum necessary. If such information is to be disposed of by a Committee member, it must be destroyed.

2.6 Members should avoid investments or business activities in relation to which they might reasonably be perceived to have access to confidential information which might give them an unfair or improper advantage over other persons.

Committee members must take care not to use their position on the Committee to influence any other member of the Committee, or an applicant or potential applicant for assistance under the Sustainable Regions programme for the purpose of obtaining any advantage for themselves, or any other person or body, whether that advantage is direct or indirect.

4.1 For the purpose of this Code of Conduct, conflicts of interest arise when members are influenced, or appear to be influenced, by personal interests in carrying out their duties as members of the Committee.
4.2 Conflicts of interest generally fall into one of two categories : pecuniary and non-pecuniary interests.

4.2.1 Pecuniary interests involve an actual or potential financial gain. A pecuniary interest could be described as an interest that a person has in a matter because of reasonable likelihood or expectation of appreciable financial gain or loss to the person, or another person or body with whom the person is associated.
4.3.3 A person is taken to have a pecuniary interest in a matter if either
· the person's spouse or de facto partner or relative, or business partner or employer of the person, has a pecuniary interest in the matter, or
· the person, or a nominee, partner or employer of the person, is a member of a company or other body that has a pecuniary interest in the matter.
4.2.3 A person is not taken to have a pecuniary interest in a matter referred to in paragraph 4.2.2:

· if the person is unaware of the relevant pecuniary interest of the spouse, de facto partner, relative or company or other body, or just because the person is a member of, or a delegate of a company or other body that has pecuniary interest in the matter, so long as the person has no beneficial interest in any shares of the company or body.

4.2.4 Non-pecuniary interests do not have a financial component. A non-pecuniary interest generally involves some form of personal advancement or gain for the individual or for others (for example, friends or relatives) in whom they have a personal interest. For example, it would include assisting with the preparation of an application for a member of an organisation.
4.3 Disclosures to be made by committee members
· a member of the Committee has a pecuniary or non-pecuniary interest in a matter being considered or about to be considered at a meeting of the Committee; and
· the interest appears to raise a conflict with the proper performance of the member's duties in relation to the consideration of the matter;
then the member shall, as soon as possible after the relevant facts have come to the member's knowledge:
(a) disclose the nature of the interest to the Chair at a meeting of the Committee; and
(b) refrain from voting on the matter.
4.4 Action to be taken when interests are declared at committee meetings

4.4.1 Any disclosures of interests and the member's consequent refraining from voting on the matter in hand will be recorded in the minutes and, where a majority of the Committee considers it necessary, the disclosure will be reported to the Minister together with any relevant advice on the matter.

4.4.2 Where a member discloses a pecuniary or non-pecuniary interest relating to a matter under consideration by the Committee that member may, with the agreement of the Committee, contribute to the Committee's discussion on the matter.

5.1 The Department of Transport and Regional Services will ensure that financial, material and human resources are provided so that the Committee is able to perform its functions. All these resources should be used for the work of the Committee only, and be used effectively.

6.1 Members must avoid giving any indication that gifts, gratuities or hospitality relating to their membership of the Committee will be accepted, either for themselves or for any other person or body, or that these may influence their advice.

6.2 Members may accept only token gifts and modest hospitality. Token gifts are taken to be those valued at around $20 or less. Hospitality is modest when it is not more than the Committee member would provide in return to that person, people or company.
6.3 If any gift, gratuity or hospitality of other than a token kind is offered, full and prompt disclosure must be made to the Chair, or the full Committee as appropriate.

7.1 Any matter that is suspected, on reasonable grounds, to concern corrupt conduct should be reported to the Chair or directly to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government.

(6) and (7) The selection and announcement of projects is a continuous process. Each region is at a different stage and applications are considered regularly at SRAC meetings. Each SRAC recommends projects to me for funding.
(8) A copy of the standard contract has been provided to Mr Ferguson.
(9) Community groups, the private sector and local government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Minister's Department administer any programs relating to illicit drug use.
(2) If so, what has been the level of expenditure on these programs in (a) 1996-97, (b) 1997-98, (c) 1998-99, (d) 1999-2000, (e) 2000-2001 and (f) 2001-2002.

(3) In relation to programs which have allowed organisations to apply for funding for the delivery of services or programs, (a) what is the name of each program and (b) what was the level of expenditure in each State in (a) 1996-97, (b) 1997-98, (c) 1998-99, (d) 1999-2000, (e) 2000-2001 and (f) 2001-2002 on each program.

(4) In relation to funding under these programs, (a) how many applications were received from within electoral divisions of (i) Chisholm, (ii) Aston, (iii) Deakin, (iv) Latrobe and (v) Casey, (b) what is the name of each organisation that submitted an application, (c) what was the purpose of the funding being sought in each case, (d) what was the value of funding sought in each case and (e) if the application was successful, (i) what level of funding was granted and (ii) in which federal electoral division is the organisation based.

(5) In relation to programs that do not provide for organisations to apply for funding, what was the level of expenditure for each program in the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98, (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The “Tough on Drugs” National Illicit Drug Strategy (NIDS) which was announced in November 1997 is the major funding program relating to illicit drug use which is administered by the Department. In addition, the Department also administers a range of licit and illicit drug programs under the National Drug Strategy (NDS).

(2) It is not possible to provide detailed information on the specific funding provided for activities under the NDS as many of the initiatives cover both licit and illicit drugs and cannot be easily disaggregated. However, under the NIDS, the Department has allocated the following funding: (a) none in 1996-1997; (b) none in 1997-1998; (c) $8.2 million in 1998-1999; (d) $50.38 million in 1999-2000; (e) $59.82 million in 2000-2001 and (f) $59.40 million in 2001-2002.
(3) (a) The Non-Government Organisation Treatment Grants Program (NGOTGP), and the Community Partnerships Initiative (CPI).

(b) The NGOTGP provides funding to non-government organisations to establish and operate new treatment services and expand or enhance existing treatment services for treating illicit drug problems. The level of expenditure under the NGOTGP to date is:

The CPI aims to encourage quality practice in community action to prevent illicit drug use and to build on existing activity occurring across Australia. The level of expenditure under the CPI to date is:
There was no expenditure in 1996-1997 and 1997-1998 for these programs as they commenced in 1998-1999.
(4) (a) Number of applications received under the NGOTGP and the CPI:
NGOTGP - the number of applications received under this program in the following electoral divisions are: (i) six in Chisholm; (ii) seven in Aston; (iii) five in Deakin;
(iv) none in Latrobe and (v) five in Casey.

CPI - the number of applications received under this program in the following electoral divisions are: (i) one in Chisholm; (ii) five in Aston; (iii) three in Deakin; (iv) one in Latrobe and (v) eight in Casey.

Note: Some of the projects are based in the suburb of Ringwood, which provides services to the electorates of Aston, Deakin and Casey. Therefore, applications received from Ringwood have been included under more than one electorate.

(b) Attachment A provides the details of the organisations who have received funding under the NGOTGP and the CPI in the identified electorates. Decisions regarding the allocation of funding under both programs were made following an assessment process which included the Australian National Council on Drugs (representing the views of the non-government sector). For confidentiality reasons the Department is not able to provide details of those organisations who applied for funding but were unsuccessful. Approval would need to be sought from these organisations before this information could be provided.
(c) to (e) Refer to (b) above.

(5) Apart from the NGOTGP and the CPI that have allowed organisations to apply for funding, the bulk of the remaining funding under the NIDS is not allocated to a particular community or communities, and are not situated in a particular electorate(s). For example, the National Illicit Drug Campaign, the Australian Drug Information Network and the Training Frontline Workers Initiative benefit all of Australia.

para.inline: NATIONAL ILLICIT DRUG STRATEGY - NON-GOVERNMENT ORGANISATION TREATMENT GRANTS PROGRAM
SUCCESSFUL APPLICATIONS IN ELECTORATES OF CHISHOLM, ASTON, DEAKIN, LATROBE AND CASEY

entry.para: Maroondah Social and Community Health Centre(Electorates of Casey, La Trobe and McEwen)
To establish a family focussed outreach substance abuse service for young people in the Shire of Yarra Ranges.
2. Knox Community Health Centre(Electorate of Aston)
To provide an accessible, quality drug counselling service to the target group within an integrated, collaborative community health team.

para.inline: NATIONAL ILLICIT DRUG STRATEGY - COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS INITIATIVE
SUCCESSFUL APPLICATIONS IN ELECTORATES OF CHISHOLM, ASTON, DEAKIN, LATROBE AND CASEY

entry.para: 1. Maroondah Social and Community Health Centre(Electorates of Casey, La Trobe and McEwen)

The “Peers for Prevention: A Demonstration” project informs parents and young people about illicit drug use and enhances parents' skills and strategies in dealing with illicit drug use to create a network of shared knowledge between young people, their parents and the broader community; and to provide a resource for use by parent/youth groups in other settings.
2. Knox Community Health Service Inc(Electorate of Aston)

The “Community Owned Drug Education” project developed a network of informal drug educators in the Knox municipality; provided formal and informal primary prevention information to parents of young people; and promoted healthy lifestyle messages to young people through drug free youth events. The project also developed a train the trainer program and conducted parent and community drug information/education sessions.
3. Ranges Community Health Service(Electorate of Casey, La Trobe and McEwen)

The “Choose Life Program” employed a community development worker to assess, plan, implement and evaluate a series of primary prevention activities centring around decision making and choices regarding young people and drug use within their social and developmental framework. Activities included educating and informing young people and the community on the risks associated with drug use, focus groups, and developing linkages with schools in the region.
4. Ranges Community Health Service(Electorate of Casey, La Trobe and McEwen)

The “CAR 26” project aims to prevent and/or reduce the uptake of illicit alcohol and other drug use by young males between the ages of 14-26 years living in the Shire of Yarra Ranges, and address road safety issues amongst this target group. In 2000 the Shire of Yarra Ranges recorded the highest road death toll in Victoria. A significant number of the deaths involved young males, and illicit drug use was a contributing factor in some of the deaths.
Knox Community Health Service Inc(Electorate of Aston)

The “SMART” (Skills, Mentoring and Resilience Training) project aims to build resilience and achieve cognitive change in the world view of young people aged between 10 and 17 years by employing a multi-strategic approach to the problems of illicit drugs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Minister administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding.
(2) If so, what are these programs.
(3) Does the Ministers Department advertise these funding opportunities.

(4) In the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98, (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002, for each of the programs listed in part (2), (A) what was the name and postal address of each organisation that sought funding from the Commonwealth, (B) what was the purpose of the funding sought in each case and (C) for successful applications, what was the level of funding provided.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes
(2) The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) Road Safety Research Grant Scheme
These grants are offered as a means to:
· promote innovative worthwhile research into road safety; and

· broaden the base of effective road safety researchers by encouraging established scientists, recent postgraduates, and commercial and community-based organisations to undertake research in the road safety field.

Applications are invited from Australasian academic research institutions and Australasian commercial or community-based organisations. The research can be into any aspect of road safety. The maximum duration of a project is twelve months, and the maximum grant available is $25,000.

The Scheme assists in alleviating the comparative interstate freight cost disadvantage incurred by the shippers of eligible non-bulk goods carried between Tasmania and the mainland. The objective of the Scheme is to provide Tasmanian industries with equal opportunities to compete in mainland markets, recognising that, unlike their mainland counterparts, Tasmanian shippers do not have the option of transporting goods interstate by road or rail. Some 1450 shippers, ranging from small sole proprietor businesses to large companies benefit from the Scheme.

para.inline: Payment Scheme for Airservices Australia Enroute Charges

quote.para: The Department manages delivery of a 3.5 year programme, commencing 1 January 2002, to subsidise Airservices Australia enroute air traffic control charges incurred by around 30 small regular public transport airlines, and those providing aero-medical services.
The Rapid Route Recovery Scheme was developed to provide short-term transitional support to restore air services to communities affected by the collapse of the Ansett Group.

The Sustainable Regions Programme provides assistance in the following eight regions: the Atherton Tablelands, Wide Bay Burnett (Qld), Far North East New South Wales, Campbelltown-Camden (NSW), Gippsland (Vic), North West & West Coast (Tas), Playford/Salisbury (SA) and Kimberley (WA) regions.
Structural adjustment programmes include:
Special Structural Adjustment Package for the South-West Forests Region of Western Australia: http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/adjustment/sw_forests/index.htm
The Newcastle Structural Adjustment Fund:
http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/adjustment/newcastle/index.htm
A new package of assistance for the Namoi Valley was announced on 9 September 2002. Details of the Namoi Valley Structural Adjustment Package are at:
http://www.ministers.dotars.gov.au/ja/releases/2002/september/A114b_2002.htm
Funding is available for projects by regional non-profit groups with strong support from their community or region. Local government bodies are also eligible to apply.
The Regional Assistance Programme (RAP) provides seed funding for community based projects from `not for profit' organisations.
The Rural Transaction (RTC) Programme ensures access for rural, regional and remote Australians to basic services that have been withdrawn from, or never existed in, small rural towns.

answer.para: Dairy Regional Assistance Programme (Dairy RAP)

quote.para: Dairy RAP assists communities that have been impacted upon by the deregulation of the dairy industry by facilitating long term employment and support for services that will lead to on-going economic and social benefits.
(3) Yes

para.inline: The ATSB Road Safety Research Grant Scheme

quote.para: The ATSB Road Safety Research grant scheme for 2002 was advertised in the Financial Review and Weekend Australian.

These include: Centrelink has information stalls at the annual Tasmanian Agfest with information on TFES and Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme; on the Centrelink and DOTARS websites; in the `Tasmanian Business Reporter' newspaper; advertised TFES in The Australian last year; and in the Commonwealth Regional Information Book.

para.inline: Payment Scheme for Airservices Australia Enroute Charges

quote.para: Airservices Australia Enroute Charges was advertised in 11 major newspapers around Australia as well as on the DOTARS website.

answer.para: Rapid Route Recovery Scheme. No

quote.para: Promoted on the DoTARS Web site http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/sustainable_regions/index.htm http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/sustainable_regions/index.htm. Funding rounds are advertised in relevant newspapers, local advisory committees and stakeholders are consulted as part of this process.

Promoted on the DoTARS Web site http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/adjustment/index.htm and funding rounds are advertised in relevant newspapers, local advisory committees and stakeholders are consulted as part of this process.

The Regional Solutions Programme is advertised in national newspapers and electronically on the DoTARS website, http://www.dotars.gov.au and http://www.regionalsolutions.gov.au as well as through the Commonwealth Government grants website, http://www.grantslink.gov.au The programme is also promoted through the Commonwealth Regional Information Service.

The Regional Assistance Programme (RAP) is promoted through the Area Consultative Committee (ACC) network. In consultation with their communities ACCs help identify local opportunities, priorities and development strategies for their regions. ACC's use various media outlets to inform communities about accessing RAP funding. The RAP is promoted through the DOTARS regional website http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/rap/index.htm and the ACC website http://www.acc.gov.au as well as the Commonwealth Regional Information Service http://www.regionalaustralia.gov.au/index.cfm and Grantslink http://www.grantslink.gov.au locations.
The RTC Secretariat can be contacted at 1800 038 160 (freecall), the RTC website at
www.dotars.gov.au/rtc and Grantslink http://www.dotars.gov.au/grantslink locations.
Dairy RAP is promoted through Departmental Web pages

http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/drap/index.htm, Grantslink http://www.grantslink.gov.au and Area Consultative Committees promote the Programme on behalf of the Department through Dairy Regional Assistance Programme facilitators.
(4) I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved in breaking down the information sought into the electoral divisions requested.

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Program Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 745)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Minister administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding.
(2) If so, what are these programs.
(3) Does the Minister's Department advertise these funding opportunities.

(4) In the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98, (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002, for each of the programs listed in part (2), (A) what was the name and postal address of each organisation that sought funding from the Commonwealth, (B) what was the purpose of the funding sought in each case and (C) for successful applications, what was the level of funding provided.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes

entry.para: National Feral Animal Control ProgramThe National Feral Animal Control Program (NFACP) has been established under the Federal Government's Natural Heritage Trust to develop and implement, in cooperation with State, Territory and Local Governments, a program to reduce the damage to agriculture and the environment caused by pest animals. The NFACP is jointly administered by the Bureau of Rural Sciences and the Biodiversity Group of Environment Australia.

Natural Heritage TrustNational Landcare Program;National Rivercare Program;Murray-Darling 2001 Program;Fisheries Action Program ;Farm Forestry Program;Australian Government Envirofund.The Federal Government's $2.5 billion Natural Heritage Trust is Australia's largest ever environmental rescue package. The Trust was set up in 1996 to help conserve and sustain Australia's environment and natural resources. In the first six years of the Trust, funding was delivered through a range of programs addressing issues relating to land, vegetation, rivers, biodiversity and coasts and seas.In the 2001 Federal Budget, the Government announced an extra $1 billion for the Trust, extending the funding for five more years from 2002-03 to 2006-07. Under revised arrangements for the extension of the Trust, individuals and community groups can undertake small projects aimed at conserving biodiversity and sustainable resource use by applying for funding through the Australian Government Envirofund.

National Action Plan for Salinity and Water QualityIndividuals or businesses are not eligible to apply directly to the Commonwealth for funding under the National Action Plan, funding is available to community-based regional bodies identified in bilateral agreements between the Commonwealth and each state and territory in which such agreements have been signed. Individuals and businesses would access funding through activities agreed to by governments in regional investment plans.

No. As funding is limited to the regional bodies identified under bilateral agreements between the Commonwealth and states and territories, availability of funding is communicated directly with these bodies on a state-by-state basis.
Environmental Management Systems Incentives ProgramCommenced on 1 July 2002 and is available to all eligible primary producers.

Great Artesian Basin Sustainability InitiativeA $31.8M investment by the Commonwealth over 5 years (July 1999 to June 2004). Together with state investments, the Initiative provides technical assistance and financial incentives to eligible owners of uncontrollable pastoral bores in the Great Artesian Basin. Assistance is available to repair bores and/or replace open earthen bore drains with piped stock water reticulation systems in the interests of reducing the total outflows from the Basin and partial recovery of artesian pressures in priority areas.
No. This is done by the responsible state agency.

Fisheries Resources Research FundThe Fisheries Resources Research Fund supports an agreed programme of independent assessment of Commonwealth fisheries management performance, as well as the development of new and improved policies for fisheries management in accordance with the specific policy streams of Fishing Industry Development and Resources Sustainability.
The Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Program (FISAP)Funded jointly with the NSW, Victorian and WA Governments and solely in Queensland. Also the Eden Region Adjustment Package.

New Industries Development ProgramThe objective of the New Industries Development Program is to accelerate efforts to assist Australian agribusiness improve its capacity to efficiently and successfully develop new, innovative, high value products, services and technologies that will generate additional medium term commercial outcomes for the benefit of Australia.

Dairy Regional Assistance ProgramDairy Regional Assistance Program is designed to assist communities that have been impacted upon by the deregulation of the diary industry. The program facilitates long term employment by supplementing business investment and provides support for services that will lead to on-going economic and social benefits for regions affected by dairy deregulation. The Department of Transport and Regional Services receives funding and is responsible for managing this program. DOTARS reports directly to Minister Truss.
No. The Department of Transport and Regional Services is responsible for managing all aspects of the program.

Australia China Agriculture Cooperation AgreementThe Australia —China Agricultural Cooperation Agreement (ACACA) provides funding for agricultural oriented exchange projects between Australia and China. It promotes agricultural cooperation between the two countries on the basis of mutual benefit and reciprocity.The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry - Australia (AFFA) and the Chinese Ministry of Agriculture (MoA) jointly fund and administer the Agreement.

AAA-Farm Innovation ProgramAAA- Farm Innovation Program provides grants to eligible Australian farming, food, fishing and forestry businesses to adopt and demonstrate innovative practices, processes, products and technologies. All four rounds of this pilot program have now been successfully completed.

Farmbis AustraliaThe FarmBis Australia program is administered by Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry - Australia. Industry organisations and companies can apply for funding under the program to develop new and innovative training and education projects to enhance the business management skills of Australia's agricultural industries.

Rural Financial Counselling ProgramThe AAA-Rural Financial Counselling Service provides funding to assist community groups who wish to provide financial counselling services to help primary producers, fishing enterprises and small rural businesses in rural areas who are experiencing financial hardship and have no source of financial advice. The program also incorporates new funding for short-term financial counselling projects to target specific regional or industry adjustment issues, either in conjunction with an existing community-based service or as a separate project instigated by an industry group or region.

Young People's Rural Networks GrantsA grants program open to any not for profit community organisation that has 18-35 year olds who work in agriculture, fisheries, forestry, food, natural resource management or related industries as its members.

answer.para: (4) I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved in breaking down the information sought into the electoral divisions requested.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing and the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Minister administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding.
(2) If so, what are these programs.
(3) Does the Minister's Department advertise these funding opportunities.

(4) In the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-1997, (ii) 1997-98 (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002, for each of the programs listed in part (2), (A) what was the name of postal address of each organisation that sought funding from the Commonwealth, (B) what was the purpose of the funding sought in each case and (C) for successful applications, what was the level of funding provided.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question on behalf of both the Minister for Health and Ageing and the Minister for Ageing:

quote.para: (1) Yes
(2) Funded programs are:
- Community Sector Support Scheme
- Research funding provided under the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 (Section 11A)
- The National Aged Care Advocacy Program (NACAP) formerly known as the Residential Aged Care Advocacy -Services Program
- Aged Care Workers Budget Initiative
- The Bush Nursing, Small Community and Regional Private Hospital Program
- The Asthma 3+ Community Support and Community Grants Program 2002
- National Child Nutrition Program
- Non-Government Organisation Treatment Grants Program (NGOTGP)
- Community Partnerships Initiative (CPI)
- 1999-2003 Diversion Program, including national education initiatives relating to needle and syringe programs
- 1999-2000 Hepatitis C Education and Prevention Budget Initiative
- Rural Chronic Disease Initiative
- Strengthening the Evidence Base
- Aged Care Innovative Pool
- Aged Care Approvals Program (conducted under Division 13 of the Aged Care Act, 1997)
- Partners in Culturally Appropriate Care
- Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Flexible Aged Care under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Aged Care -Strategy, 1994
- Community Aged Care Package Program
- Extended Aged Care at Home Program
- The National Respite for Carers Program
- The National Continence Management Strategy Innovative Grants Program
- Quality Use of Medicines Evaluation Program
- After Hours Primary Medical Care Grants Development Program
- National Suicide Prevention Strategy
- National Palliative Care Program
- The Regional Health Services Program (RHSP)
- The Multipurpose Services (MPS) Program
- The Rural Health Support Education & Training (RHSET) Program

(3) Yes. (Some funding programs are advertised, however, it is dependent on the guidelines/criteria for each individual funding program. In addition, some programs are fully subscribed and therefore advertising is not necessary.)
(4) I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved in breaking down the information sought into the electoral divisions requested.
