talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has any embryonic stem cell research been carried out in Australia prior to the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 being passed.
(2) Has any funding been granted for the establishment of a centre for the purpose of carrying out research on embryonic stem cells; if so, what sum has been granted.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. The Council of Australian Governments agreed that research with existing cell lines will be permitted to continue in Australia subject to observance of conditions set by the National Health and Medical Research Council. The Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 will regulate the use of excess assisted reproductive technology (ART) embryos for the derivation of new embryonic stem cell lines.

(2) I am advised that there has not been any funding provided for the establishment of a centre specifically for purpose of carrying out research on embryonic stem cells. However, two grants have been made or offered for the establishment of centres to undertake research on a range of different types of stem cells as well as research into tissue engineering more broadly. The Biotechnology Centre of Excellence grant of $43.6 million, awarded to the National Stem Cell Centre, is for research on animal and adult stem cells as well as embryonic stem cells. Research on excess ART embryos to create new embryonic stem cell lines will only occur if the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 is passed. The government grant to the National Stem Cell Centre is not dependent on the Bill being passed. An offer of $5.5 million has been made to the National Centre for Advanced Cell Engineering over 2002-03 to 2005-06 to support the establishment of infrastructure to provide capacity to undertake stem cell and related systems research directed at tissue engineering. This contract has yet to be finalised.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 22 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) In a letter to the Police Federation of Australia, dated 1 October 2001, did he state that the Heads of Government Agreement that deals with the preservation age for superannuation schemes was being reviewed by the Commonwealth Treasury.

(2) Has the review by the Commonwealth Treasury made a decision regarding the application of the preservation principles contained in the agreement to superannuation schemes for police officers; if so, what is the decision; if not, why not.
(3) Which States raised concerns regarding the application of the preservation principles to superannuation schemes for police officers.
(4) What steps will the Federal Government take to facilitate an agreement with the States to exempt police superannuation from the Heads of Government Agreement.
(5) Does the Government support the police officers' submission that they be able to access their superannuation at the age of 55.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) On 1 October 2001, I wrote to Mr Mark Burgess of the Police Federation of Australia in response to a letter from him dated 2 July 2001. I informed Mr Burgess that the Heads of Government Agreement that deals with public sector superannuation schemes was being reviewed by the Treasury and that, as part of that process, the preservation age concerns raised by the Police Federation would receive consideration.

(2) I am informed that the Treasury has since completed its review of the preservation age requirements for police that apply under the Heads of Government Agreement. At present under the Agreement, superannuation schemes that are exempt from the provisions of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (SIS Act) are required to adhere to the principles of Commonwealth retirement incomes policy.

The government has decided that it would not be appropriate to change the preservation age requirements of police under the Heads of Government Agreement. Accordingly, police will continue to be subject to the general preservation age requirements that are in place to deal with the challenges posed by an ageing population and to ensure that superannuation is used for retirement income purposes.

(3) I understand that certain states raised concerns with the former Assistant Treasurer in the context of the review of the Heads of Government Agreement. However, the government's position is based on the desirability of having a uniform national superannuation policy.

(4) I am informed that the current preservation age arrangements that apply to police under the Heads of Government Agreement are consistent with those that apply to other sectors where work is physically demanding. Since November 1991, those entering the defence force, for example, are subject to standard preservation age requirements. Moreover, not all police are in superannuation schemes covered by the Heads of Government Agreement. The government is mindful that any change to the Agreement would, therefore, lead to differential treatment of police between those covered by the Agreement and those subject to general preservation age requirements under the SIS Act.

(5) I am informed that on 20 September 2002 the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer wrote to the Police Federation on behalf of the government informing them that the government would not be changing the preservation age requirements for police under the Heads of Government Agreement. It should be noted, however, that consistent with requirements under the SIS Act, these police are currently entitled to access their superannuation at age 55. The increase in the general preservation age from 55 to 60 years is to be phased in between 2015 and 2025.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is question No. 2 which appeared on 13 February 2002 on the first Notice Paper of the 40th Parliament the same question No. 2476 which first appeared on the Notice Paper on 28 March 2001 during the 39th Parliament.
(2) Did he receive a letter from the Speaker following my request to the Speaker on 20 August 2001 to write to him seeking an early reply to question No. 2476 under standing order 150.
(3) Did he receive a further letter from the Speaker following my request to the Speaker on 14 May 2002 to again write to him seeking an answer to question No. 2 under standing order 150.

(4) Did he receive yet another letter from the Speaker following yet another request by me to the Speaker on 19 August 2002 to write to him seeking an answer to question No. 2 under standing order 150.
(5) When will he answer question No. 2.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (4) Yes.
(5) I refer the Honourable Member to House of Representatives Hansard of 15 October 2002 Page No. 7621.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to question No. 678, does former Senator Colston's recent demonstrated capacity to undertake both motor vehicle and air travel indicate a change in circumstances whereby the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) might consider reviewing the current state of health of Dr Colston with a view to assessing his capacity to stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if so, what might that review involve; if not, why not.

(2) Since July 1999, was the DPP advised on each occasion of the full details of Dr Colston's taxpayer-funded motorcar or aircraft travel; if so, what was the DPP advised and what action did the DPP take to satisfy himself of the nature of Dr Colston's travel; if not, why not.

(3) Since July 1999, did the DPP inquire of Dr Colston, or any of the medical practitioners treating him, whether any of Dr Colston's taxpayer-funded travel was for the sole purpose of medical treatment; if so, what was he advised; if not, why not.

(4) In light of the independent medical assessments by two eminent medical specialists who reported on Dr Colston on 14 and 19 May 1999 that his life expectancy was only months and which led to the DPP at that time determining that there was no prospect of Dr Colston being fit to stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts, is the DPP prepared to invite Dr Colston to offer himself for fresh medical examination and assessment by appropriately qualified expert medical specialists; if not; why not.

(5) Will the DPP initiate immediate up-to-date medical assessments of Dr Colston by appropriately qualified expert medical specialists with a view to establishing Dr Colston's capacity to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if not, why, not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I refer to my answer to Question on Notice 678.
(2) Advice is being sought on Dr Colston's fitness to stand trial. The DPP has requested that travel be taken into consideration.

(4) The DPP's decision to discontinue was based on medical opinion as to fitness to stand trial. As part of the review of this matter the DPP has requested that Dr Colston be further independently examined.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 28 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Sydney Airport Noise Complaints Line record statistics for the number of complaints made to the line in the evening after 5 p.m. when the staffed service ends; if so, what are the figures so far for 2002 and what proportion of those calls are from people living under the flightpath of the western runway.
(2) Why are the phones not staffed between 5 p.m. and 11 p.m. when families to the west of the airport generally experience the worst noise.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. The Sydney Airport Noise Complaints Line records statistics for the number of complaints made to the line in the evening from 5pm when the staffed service ends. The year to date figures to August 2002 show that 1230 complaints have been received during out of service hours. 14% (172) of these complaints were received from people living under the flight path of the western runway.

(2) Calls that are made between the hours of 5:00pm and 11:00pm are recorded on an answering service. Each call is then personally responded to the following day, assuming that the caller has left a message.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 29 August 2002:

question.para: (1) For each financial year from 1996-1997 to 2000-2001, how many alleged cases of fraud involving dishonestly obtaining a benefit by deception or other means were identified or reported for evaluation by Commonwealth Departments or agencies in accordance with the Commonwealth's Fraud Control Guidelines.

(2) For each financial year from 1996-1997 to 2000-2001, how many alleged cases of fraud were identified or reported for each Department or agency submitting reports to his Department in accordance with the Fraud Control Guidelines.

(3) For each financial year from 1996-1997 to 2000-2001, how many alleged cases of fraud were (a) investigated by the responsible Department or agency, (b) referred to the Australian Federal Police, (c) referred to State or Territory police or (d) not pursued.

(4) For each financial year from 1996-1997 to 2000-2001, how many fraud investigations resulted in (a) referral to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, (b) prosecution by the responsible Department or agency or (c) no further action because insufficient evidence or suspects resigned, retired or otherwise left the organisation.

(5) For each financial year from 1996-1997 to 2000-2001, how many persons employed by or serving as contractors to the Commonwealth Government were successfully prosecuted for offences involving fraud against the Commonwealth.

(6) For each financial year from 1996-1997 to 2000-2001, what was the estimated value of losses resulting from alleged fraud reported by each Department and agency in accordance with the Commonwealth Fraud Control Guidelines.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Fraud information provided by departments and agencies to the Attorney-General's Department for the purposes of compiling an Annual Fraud Report to the Minister for Justice and Customs, during the financial years of 1996-97 to 2000-01, was based upon the requirements of the Fraud Control Policy of the Commonwealth 1994 (the Policy) introduced by the previous Labor Government in 1994.

Under the Policy there was no requirement for departments or agencies to provide my Department with much of the fraud information sought by the honourable member. I am therefore only able to provide answers to his questions in a limited sense, that is, where the previous Policy required departments and agencies to provide my Department with the information sought.

I should also indicate that the type of detailed fraud information sought by the honourable member reflects the requirements of this Government's Commonwealth Fraud Control Guidelines (the Guidelines) which I released on 13 May 2002 and which becomes operative for the 2002-03 financial year.

(1), (2) and (3) Under the fraud Policy that operated during the period of 1996-97 to 2000-01 departments and agencies were required to provide details of the number of fraud cases referred to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the number of cases handled administratively by the department or agency.

(4) My Department does not hold this information. Under the fraud Policy that operated during the period of 1996-97 to 2000-01, departments and agencies were not required to provide details on the number of cases referred to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions; the number of cases prosecuted by departments and agencies; or the number of cases where no further action was taken.

(5) My Department does not hold this information. Under the fraud Policy that operated during the period of 1996-97 to 2000-01 departments and agencies were not required to provide details of the number of persons employed by or serving as contractors to the Commonwealth Government that were successfully prosecuted for offences involving fraud against the Commonwealth.

(6) The information that departments and agencies were able to provide on losses under the fraud Policy did not distinguish between losses attributable to fraud and other losses and waivers. Accordingly, after 1996-97 this process of reporting on losses was discontinued.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Who carried out the post-mortem examination following the death of a 28 year old Afghan asylum seeker in August on Nauru.
(2) What was the determined cause of death.
(3) Given the age of the man and no reported signs of disease or self-harm, why was his body not flown to the nearest available facility where a proper autopsy could be conducted.
(4) What arrangements have been made for the return of the man's body to Afghanistan.
(5) What costs has been incurred and who will meet those costs.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Following the death, the Nauru Coroner ordered an autopsy, which was conducted on Nauru by a pathologist from the Victorian College of Forensic Medicine.

(2) The precise cause of death could not be determined despite extensive post mortem examination including microscopic and toxicological analysis. There was, however, no change to the conclusion of the Chief Medical Officer of Nauru that the death was of natural causes. The pathologist indicated that being unable to find the precise cause of death is not unusual for sudden deaths in this age group. The pathologist raised the possibility of cardiac arrhythmia or epilepsy.
(3) The autopsy was conducted on Nauru under Nauruan law. The pathologist did, however, take tissue samples for analysis in Australia.

(4) In accordance with the wishes of the family of the deceased, International Organization for Migration (IOM) staff arranged for the body of the deceased to be repatriated to Afghanistan for burial. The body was returned to Afghanistan on 15 September.
(5) The IOM has advised that the cost of the autopsy, embalming and repatriation of the body to Afghanistan is in the order of $39,000. The Australian Government meets IOM costs.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 16 September 2002:

question.para: Will he bring up to date the information that he gave concerning conventions in the Hague Conference system in his answer to question No. 2743 (Hansard, 17 September 2001, page 30816)?

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Australia has ratified or acceded to nine Hague Conventions. There has been no change to this number since my previous answer of 17 September 2001.
The Attorney-General's Department's work on Hague Convention matters is currently focussed on:

· administrative work required under Hague Conventions to which Australia is already a party (including the 1970 Convention on the Taking of Evidence Abroad in Civil or Commercial Matters, the 1980 Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, and the 1993 Convention on Protection of Children and Co-operation in respect of Intercountry Adoption;
· work with relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory agencies on ratification of other Hague Conventions with priority currently being given to:

· The 1996 Convention on Jurisdiction, Applicable Law, Recognition, Enforcement and Co-operation in respect of Parental Responsibility and Measures for the Protection of Children. The Family Law Amendment (Child Protection Convention) Act 2002 implemented those aspects of the Convention within Commonwealth jurisdiction. The Commonwealth is working with States and Territories on legislation that will put Australia in a position to ratify the Convention;
· work towards the preparation of new Conventions on:
· Jurisdiction, Recognition and Enforcement of Judgments in Civil and Commercial Matters; and
· the Law Applicable to Certain Rights in Respect of Securities Held with an Intermediary.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 16 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 601 (Hansard, 20 August 2002, page 5296) concerning assistance to Australiawide Airlines, what agreement does the Government have with Australiawide to continue to provide air services to regional routes solely serviced by Kendall or Hazelton beyond the six months referred to.
(2) What are the routes solely served by Kendall or Hazelton covered by the agreement.

(3) Does the agreement detail the number of flights on these regional routes solely served by Kendall or Hazelton; if so, how does that service compare with that previously provided by Kendall or Hazelton and what mechanism will be used to ensure those routes remain serviced by Australiawide.
(4) Does the agreement to pay $5 million to Australiawide provide for any other payment by the Government across any portfolio now or in the future.
(5) How many dollars remain in the Rapid Route Recovery scheme program after payment of the $5 million to Australiawide.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The agreement the Government has secured is as outlined in my previous answer.

(2) Adelaide - Broken Hill, Adelaide - Ceduna, Adelaide - Cooper Pedy, Adelaide - Olympic Dam, Dubbo - Broken Hill, Melbourne - Sale/Traralgon, Melbourne - Albury, Melbourne - Merimbula, Melbourne - Portland, Melbourne - Wagga-Wagga (via Albury), Melbourne - King Island, Sydney - Orange, Sydney - Bathurst, Sydney - Parkes, Sydney - Broken Hill, Sydney - Narrandera, Sydney - Griffith, Sydney - Moruya, Sydney - Merimbula, Sydney - Lismore.
(3) No. The Agreement requires Australiawide to maintain services on the route. The frequency of those services is a matter for Australiawide's commercial judgement.
(4) No
(5) There are currently no moneys available for further payments under the program beyond those to be provided under the Australiawide agreement.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 16 September 2002:

question.para: Further to his discussion paper on university finances entitled “Setting Firm Foundations” and Table 1 which lists distribution of HECS debts, is he able to provide in the same format what the distribution of HECS debts is and the average HECS debt of (a) all HECS debtors who have not made any repayments and who first incurred a HECS debt in or prior to 1999, (b) graduates who have not made any repayments and who first incurred a HECS debt in or prior to 1999, (c) all HECS debtors who have not made any repayments, (d) graduates who have not made any repayments, (e) all HECS debtors who first incurred a HECS debt between 1997 and 1999 and who have not made any repayments and (f) graduates who first incurred a HECS debt between 1997 and 1999 and who have not made any repayments.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) administers HECS repayments. The HECS management information system used by the ATO for this purpose is not designed to generate all of the data requested by the honourable member. The ATO data system can only identify HECS debtors as a single group. It cannot distinguish between graduates with a HECS debt and current students with a HECS debt. Thus, only responses to parts (a), (c), and (e) of the honourable member's question can be provided.

As requested by the honourable member, the data has been presented in the same format as the data in Table 1 of the issues paper Setting Firm Foundations: Financing Australian Higher Education (DEST, July 2002) which shows the distribution of HECS debts by level of debt, as per the table below.

entry.para: (a) Number of HECS debtors who have not made any repayments and who first incurred a HECS debt in or prior to 1999
(c) Total number of HECS debtors who have not made any repayments
(e) Number of HECS debtors who first incurred a HECS debt between 1997 and 1999 and who have not made any repayments

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 17 September 2002:

quote.para: In (a) 1998, (b) 1999, (c) 2000 and (d) 2001, what percentage of births occurred by Caesarean section in (i) each State and Territory and (ii) in (A) private and (B) public hospitals in each State and Territory.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The percentage of births that occurred by Caesarean section is attached at Table 1.
Table 1
Percent of separations(a) of caesarian deliveries, by year, hospital type and State of treating hospital, acute and unknown episodes, Australia, 1997-98 to 2000-01
Source: Commonwealth Department of Health and Aged Care, National Morbidity (Casemix) Database.
(a) Figures include ADRGs O01 Caesarian Delivery, O02 Vaginal Delivery with complicating O.R. procedure, and O60 Vaginal Delivery.
n.a. Not available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 18 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen a report titled “Hospital crisis as nurses walk out the door” by Mark Metherell and Joseph Kerr on page 1 of The Sydney Morning Herald on 17 September 2002.
(2) Will Australia's nursing shortage rise six-fold to 30,000 in four years without major changes to stem the losses from hospitals; if not, why not.
(3) What incentives will the Government introduce for students to enter nursing training courses.
(4) What major changes will the Government introduce to improve the (a) retention and (b) working conditions of nurses in Australia.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes

(2) The National Review of Nursing Education contracted a number of bodies of research. One report, by Shah, C. and Burke, G. (Job Growth and Replacement in Nursing Occupations) projects 31,000 openings in positions for new entrants across the period 2001-2006, from directors of nursing to assistants in nursing. The paper provides these projections to enable estimates of the numbers needing to be trained to fill various types of positions. It provides no estimate of the relationship between demand and supply.
(3) The Commonwealth currently provides the following:
(a) Scholarships for undergraduate nursing in aged care - $26.3 million over four years (2002 - 2006).
(b) Support for aged care workers to access education, training or upskilling opportunities - $21.2million over four years (2002 - 2006).
(c) The Australian Remote and Rural Nursing Scholarship Program - $13 million over four years (2001 - 2005) to improve access to undergraduate nursing education for rural and regional students.

(d) The Puggy Hunter Memorial Scholarship Scheme - $1.23 million over five academic years (2002 - 2006) for 44 undergraduate scholarships for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in medicine, nursing and Aboriginal health worker courses.

(e) Remote and Rural Nursing - $5.2 million over four years (2002-2006) for 400 nursing scholarships per annum to assist former nurses in rural and remote areas who wish to return to work in the non-acute sector, ie. private health, aged care and community health sector.
(4) The employment of nurses is a State and Territory Government responsibility.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 18 September 2002:

question.para: (1) How many (a) permanent and (b) casual drivers are employed by Comcar in each State and Territory.
(2) How many (a) permanent and (b) casual employees are engaged in non-driving duties in each State and Territory and what are their designations.
(3) Did Comcar have responsibility for the supervision of Comcar drivers during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM), if not, which Department did have responsibility.

(4) During CHOGM, how many employees of Comcar, not engaged in CHOGM, travelled to Queensland and (a) who were they, (b) what was the cost of their travel and accommodation and (c) what was the purpose of their visit to Queensland.

(5) Over the last 7 financial years, (a) what training or consultative seminars have been held for management of Comcar, (b) where were such seminars conducted and (c) what was the itemised full cost of each seminar or consultation.

(6) With respect to the duties of drivers and the need for a safe working environment, (a) what is the policy of Comcar on the safety practice of encouraging drivers on long trips to stop every two hours for a break and (b) are drivers required to take such fatigue breaks; if not, why not.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (2) (a) and (b) COMCAR's non-driving staff represent 17.6 per cent of total staff. The bulk of the staff represented in the table are operational staff - engaged in call centre and allocations duties as well as depot operations in all States and the ACT.

entry.para: 1 SES 13 EXEC 2**2 EXEC 14 APS 64.5 APS 55 APS 417 APS 3

answer.para: * includes full-time and part-time staff
** one non-ongoing

(3) While the CHOGM Task Force (as part of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet) was responsible for allocating work to drivers (as the client) during CHOGM, COMCAR continued to have responsibility for supervision (including salary) of drivers during the event.
(4) Nil

(5) Over the last seven financial years, COMCAR's driver training has accounted for 87 per cent of COMCAR's training budget. The remaining 13 per cent has been expended on non-driving staff as follows.

entry.para: Details are unavailable - due to change in financial management information system. Totals are taken from the break-up of costs prepared at the time.
Details are unavailable - due to change in financial management information system. Totals are taken from the break-up of costs prepared at the time

answer.para: (6) Standard industry fatigue management principles are used to ensure drivers work in a safe environment. COMCAR's policy is in line with these principles and is consistent with industry standards for professional drivers. Accordingly, drivers are encouraged to take a break at least every five hours. In practice, the nature of COMCAR activities means that more frequent breaks are generally achieved.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 23 September 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard, 16 September 2002, page 6245) concerning the specialist unit he has created in his Department in relation to the Government's review of the higher education sector, what are the details of the industrial relations expertise he has brought into the process to inform the debate.
(2) What is the name of each person consulted on industrial relations in or by this unit and from which Department, agency or organisation did they come.
(3) Are these persons being engaged under a contract or agreement; if so, what is the monetary value of any contract or agreement.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) A senior officer from the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) was seconded to the Higher Education Secretariat to provide advice on Industrial Relations issues.

entry.para: Department of Employment and Workplace Relations
Australian Council of Deans of Education
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
Department of Education, Science and Training
Department of Education, Science and Training
Department of Education, Science and Training
Department of Employment and Workplace Relations

quote.para: (3) The secondee from DEWR was engaged by agreement between the Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST) and DEWR. The salary of this representative was paid for by the home department whilst on secondment to DEST. No other person was engaged under contract or by agreement in relation to industrial relations matters.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 September 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of a new automated machine-made pap test slide by medical practitioners in place of, or in addition to, a conventional pap smear.
(2) How common is the use of an automated machine-made pap test slide.
(3) Is a Medicare rebate not available for the preparation, microscopic examination and reporting of an automated machine-made Pap test slide.
(4) Will the Minister consider providing a Medicare rebate for the preparation, microscopic examination and reporting of an automated machine-made pap test slide; if so, when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) The Commonwealth does not collect this information.
(3) A rebate is available for automated reading of conventional Papanicolaou cytology slides but is not available for cervical cytology tests using liquid based slide preparation techniques.

(4) The Government will consider Medicare rebates for automated machine-made Pap test slides following a broader review of cervical cytology techniques being carried out by the Commonwealth's Medical Services Advisory Committee and expected to be completed in early 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the view of an eminent American Director of Neurosurgery Dr Charles Burton that it does not appear that any significant study or due diligence was undertaken in regard to Iophendylate at the time the product was introduced or over the almost half century of its international use; if so, does the Minister accept that view.
(2) Is the Minister aware of any evidence that shows that the producers of Iophendylate monitored adverse effects or continuing safety and efficacy of the product.

(3) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the views of Associate Professor Palmer that a causal relationship between Iophendylate and chronic Arachnoiditis was well established in studies undertaken in the 1950s; if so, does the Minister accept that view.

(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a 1995 report of the NSW Health Department's Radiology Advisory Committee which acknowledged that Myodil is a cause of Arachnoiditis, a condition which may result in chronic severe and debilitating pain; if so, does the Minister accept that view.
(5) Is it a fact that Iophendylate was never evaluated by the Australian Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).

(6) Was one sufferer, Mr Derek Morrison, advised by the TGA in 1995 that Mr Morrison would have to write to the US Food and Drug Administration directly to obtain a copy of the initial licence for Iophendylate and that the TGA does not have access to the information.

(7) Was the company that imported and distributed Pantopaque advised by the Therapeutic Goods Branch in June 1978 that the company was involved in unauthorised distribution of the product which had not been restricted to the approved end users but apparently supplied all parts of the Commonwealth.
(8) What action was taken against the company for unauthorised distribution.
(9) What evaluation was undertaken at any time concerning the safety and suitability of the use of Iophendylate by Australian authorities and what reports did the Therapeutic Goods Branch consider.
(10) On what basis did the Therapeutic Goods Branch grant general marketing approval of Pantopaque on 9 October 1979.
(11) Is it a fact that the removal of Pantopaque and Myodil through aspiration was not universally practised in Australia.

(12) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the advice of The NSW Radiology Advisory Committee which in 1995 stated that Myodil was not always removed following Myelography; if so, does the Minister accept that advice.
(13) Were there standard Departmental and medical procedures which required aspiration by doctors and hospitals.
(14) How many patients undergoing Myelography procedures were left with the dye intact and with no aspiration conducted.
(15) Has the TGA the responsibility to reassure the Australian community that drugs in use are safe, effective and meet national quality standards.

(16) Is there a need for an independent inquiry to investigate the (a) effects of exposure to the chemical Iophendylate, marketed under the name Pantopaque and Myodil, (b) basis on which Iophendylate was licensed, marketed and used in Australia and (c) social and economic costs arising from the disease.

(17) Does the Chemically Induced Adhesive Arachnoiditis Sufferers of Australia group play a valuable role in assisting and counselling sufferers and as such deserves a commitment of resources and financial assistance from the Government.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) & (3) Yes. I am aware of the views of Dr Burton and Professor Palmer. I am also aware that iophendylate dyes were introduced into European and North American countries and Australia before modern evaluation and regulatory requirements for medicines were introduced. I am also aware that from the early 1970's, arachnoiditis was mentioned in the prescribing information as a possible adverse outcome of myelography using iophendylate dyes.
(2) Yes. The sponsors of iophendylate updated the prescribing information concerning these dyes based on monitoring of safety and effectiveness.
(4) I have been advised that enquiries of the NSW Health Department have been unable to establish the existence of such a report.

(5) No. In the late 1970's the Therapeutic Goods Administration's predecessor, the Therapeutic Goods Branch of the then Department of Health, evaluated an application to register the iophendylate dye, Pantopaque, for general marketing in Australia. This application was approved in October 1979.
(6) The TGA is not able to substantiate any such advice from its records.
(7) Yes.

(8) The Therapeutic Goods Branch of the Department took the matter up with the company directly and also asked the company to finalise outstanding matters relating to its application for general marketing approval of Pantopaque, which was under evaluation at that time.

(9) -(10) A general marketing application for Pantopaque was evaluated during the 1970's. Such applications need to be supported by data related to chemistry and quality control, animal studies and evidence of the drug's safe use in humans.

The sponsor submitted chemistry and quality control data related to Pantopaque, a list of scientific publications related to the use of Pantopaque and all labels, product information and promotional literature intended for use in Australia. All of this material was evaluated by the Therapeutic Goods Branch.
General marketing approval for Pantopaque was granted with the following conditions:
(a) all reports of suspected adverse reactions or related experiences were to be provided immediately on receipt;
(b) any proposed changes to the chemistry and quality control details were to be forwarded for approval prior to implementation; and
(c) any proposed amendments to the product information were to be forwarded for approval prior to distribution.

(11) -(13) The Commonwealth cannot comment about the way in which individual doctors or the medical profession in general conduct their professional practice, as this is an area that the Commonwealth has no direct power or authority over. Medical practice is regulated at the local level by the various State or Territory Medical Boards and by State or Territory legislation.

I am advised that the prescribing information for health professionals for Myodil from the early 1970's stated that the product should be removed after the myelographic procedure, and warned about the possibility of arachnoiditis. Once formally approved in 1979, the prescribing information for Pantopaque contained similar information for health prescribers.
(14) It is not known how many patients undergoing myelography procedures were left with the dye intact and with no aspiration conducted.

(15) The TGA is responsible for administering the provisions of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 (the Act). The objective of the Act is to provide for the establishment and maintenance of a national system of controls relating to the quality, safety, efficacy and timely availability of therapeutic goods.

(16) -(17) There is no basis for conducting such an inquiry. These dyes were used by doctors to diagnose and manage serious conditions of the spine, such as tumours and herniated discs and were the best method available at the time they were introduced to the market and for many years thereafter. The availability of these dyes in Australia preceded Commonwealth involvement in medicine regulation.

Information was provided to doctors about the risks of these dyes, and how to avoid adverse effects of such procedures, such as arachnoiditis. It is the role of the treating doctor to assess the risks and benefits of treatments for their patients and to make the best decision keeping their patient's interests in mind. It must be remembered that these dyes were the best available technology when they were primarily used 20-40 years ago. It would not be appropriate to judge decisions made by doctors at that time against currently available technologies.

As is appropriate, allegations of clinical practice issues concerning myelography and these dyes should be dealt with in the courts and through medical practice complaints mechanisms operated by the States and Territories. There have also been actions taken in court against those companies supplying the products in Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 26 September 2002:

quote.para: (1) What are the arrangements for the provision of sanitary products to female immigration detainees.
(2) How many tampons or pads are female detainees entitled to at a time.
(3) How often are they allowed to request tampons or pads.
(4) What is the process for female detainees to follow when requesting tampons or pads.
(5) Following a request, how are tampons or pads delivered to female detainees.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (5) Under the Immigration Detention Standards Australasian Correctional Management (ACM) is required to operate in a manner that preserves the dignity and privacy of all detainees including females. Request and distribution arrangements for sanitary products are therefore established to ensure that female detainees can be provided with their sanitary products in the most discreet manner possible.

Each Immigration Detention Facility has individual arrangements in place for the distribution of sanitary products to female immigration detainees. These arrangements are tailored to meet the needs of female detainees at each centre and the arrangements take into account the physical layout (infrastructure) of each centre, the composition of ACM staff (availability of female ACM officers) and the profile of the detainee population.
The individual arrangements operating at each centre are as follows:
Baxter Immigration Detention Facility

· Upon verbal request to a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member all female detainees are provided with sanitary napkins from a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member. ACM has advised that tampons are provided on request. However, tampons are not generally a popular product among the female detainee population.
· Female detainees are given a three months supply of sanitary products at the time of each request.
· They may seek further supplies when they foresee that their three months supply will run out.
· Sanitary products may be obtained from the nurse who is located at the nurses' station in their compound.
· Sanitary products are supplied in discreet bags.
Perth Immigration Detention Centre
· Various sanitary products are available to all female detainees.
· There is no restriction on the supply of sanitary products.
· There is no restriction on the number of requests.
· Female detainees usually ask a female ACM officer on duty for sanitary products or they can put in a written request to an ACM officer (preferably a female officer).
· On receipt of a request, an officer (preferably a female officer) will deliver the sanitary product to the female detainee by hand in packet form in a manner that is discreet.
Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre

· Female detainees are able to access sanitary products by requesting the products from ACM Welfare Officers. Sanitary pads are supplied by ACM to female detainees, or they may purchase tampons from the shop if they wish.
· Once a request has been made, a female detainee is provided with one packet of sanitary pads.
· Detainees may submit requests as often as necessary.
· Female detainees submit a request to an ACM Welfare Officer in order to obtain sanitary pads.
· Female detainees can collect sanitary pads from the ACM Welfare Officer on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.
Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre
· Sanitary products are available in each compound from the ACM administration office block which houses provisions for the detainees. There is always at least one female ACM officer on duty.
· There is no limit placed on the number of pads or tampons available for distribution.
· Female detainees may request sanitary products as often as necessary.
· Female detainees may request sanitary products from a female ACM officer in the compound, as there is always at least one female officer on duty.
· Sanitary products are issued in packages that are discreetly wrapped.
Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre
· Sanitary products are stored at the ACM officer post in Charlie block dormitory. A small supply of sanitary products is also stored in the medical clinic.

· Upon request to a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member, a female detainee is provided with sufficient products to last five to six days. Most requests are for sanitary napkins, not tampons.
· There is no restriction on the number of requests made.
· Female detainees may either speak to medical staff, or to an ACM female officer, or they may request the products in writing.
· Either medical staff or female ACM officers provide the sanitary products to the detainees.
Villawood Immigration Detention Centre
· As the majority of female detainees are housed in LIMA compound, which is fully staffed by ACM female officers, sanitary products are stored in the compound.
· Sanitary pads are issued five or six at a time (the female detainees have indicated that this is their preference), while tampons are provided in sealed packs of ten.
· Sanitary products are provided when required and on request.
· Female detainees, including those in the general compound, verbally request sanitary products from a female ACM LIMA compound staff officer.
· Pads are issued in discreet bags, while the tampon packs are small enough to be placed in a pocket or small bag.
Maribyrnong Immigration Detention Centre
· Sanitary products are available from the ACM female dormitory officer.
· There is no restriction on the supply of sanitary products.
· There is no restriction on the number of requests.
· Female detainees can request sanitary products from the ACM female dormitory officer.
· Sanitary products are delivered to the detainees by hand.
Curtin Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (now closed)
· Sanitary napkins were supplied upon request. Tampons were not popular with the female detainees.

· Supply was consistent with detainees' monthly requirements, with a slight oversupply rather than undersupply of the products to the detainees occurring as a general rule, in order to ensure detainees' needs were fully met.
· When required or anticipated to be required.
· Female detainees would attend the welfare area where products were dispensed through the assistance of a female detainee who assisted ACM staff in the area.
· Supplies were delivered in discreet bags.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say whether Qantas still issues metal cutlery to its business and first class passengers and issues plastic cutlery to its economy passengers.
(2) Is he able to say whether there are other airlines in the world that still use metal cutlery on flights.
(3) Is he able to say whether the Qantas Chairman's Lounge or Qantas Club issues only plastic cutlery.
(4) Has Qantas received a different threat assessment for passengers transiting the Chairman's Lounge or Qantas Club.
(5) Is it Qantas view that passengers lose all possibility of being a security threat once they board their flights.
(6) Has Qantas received advice that terrorist threats will only come from economy passengers.
(7) Has or will he advise Qantas management that all of the 11 September 2001 suicide terrorists were booked in either first class or the front section of their flights.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Additional Security Measures do not distinguish between economy and other passengers. Airlines are permitted to use for meal services plastic knives, rounded blade butter knives with non-serrated edges or other types of metal knives approved by the Department. The manner in which Qantas issues these knives in-flight is a matter for them.
(2) Yes.

(3) The issue of plastic knives and cutlery (cutlery does not include metal knives) is permitted for the purposes of food consumption by concessionaires and airline lounges that are located in sterile areas.
(4) -(6) These questions should be directed to Qantas.
(7) Such information has been publicly reported.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 September 2002:

quote.para: Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 682 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 6806), what is the time taken for payment processing for services given by medical specialists under the Repatriation Private Patient Scheme.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Memorandum of Understanding between the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) and the Department of Veterans' Affairs states that payment of accounts are to be made within 28 days from date of lodgement with the HIC. The HIC advises that 99% of medical accounts are paid within 28 days of date of lodgement. I am advised that the 1% of accounts which take longer than 28 days to finalise involve issues that require clarification/resolution with the provider.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

quote.para: In regard to the announcement of Australia's commitment to the Joint Strike Fighter, was a (a) financial and (b) technical comparison made with alternative bidders, Eurofighter Typhoon programme and Dassault Rafael; if so, what was the mechanism used.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The decision to commence negotiations to enter the Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) System Development and Demonstration (SDD) programme was based on both financial and technical comparisons of the full range of bidders. Defence sought technical and costing information via issue of a Request for Information in November 2001. Information on the JSF was provided through a series of briefings to Defence personnel.
On the basis of available information, an assessment was made that:
· the JSF represents a leap in technology/capability over its competitors; and
· SDD partnership offers substantial opportunities for Australian industry.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 551 (Hansard, 29 August 2002, page 5826), what is the timeline involved in the installation of an integrated perimeter security fence and associated security and lighting system at Maribyrnong Detention Centre.
(2) What were the dates for (a) final approval for the project, (b) starting work on the fences installation and (c) final completion.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Tender processes for the design and construction of the new perimeter commenced in May 2001 with the completion of Detail Design/Contract Documentation. Construction commenced in July 2001 and operational testing and commissioning commenced in December 2001.
(2) (a) Tender documents were approved in early May 2001.
(b) Installation of the fence commenced on 6 July 2001.
(b) Final completion will not be reached until all operational testing and commissioning is completed and there is acceptance that the defect liability period has expired.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

question.para: Further to the answer to Question No. 867 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 7071), of the people residing in postcodes within or shared by the electoral boundaries of the division of Calwell, what is the level of outstanding or accumulated HECS debt, in dollar terms, by postcode for people (a) currently enrolled in tertiary study and (b) not currently enrolled in university study.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) and (b) The following table lists the number of people with a HECS debt and the outstanding HECS debt for those people by postcode in the Calwell electorate. The data has been split between those who are currently enrolled in university study and those who are not.

The minor differences in the numbers of HECS debtors provided in the earlier response to Question No. 867 asked by the honourable member and the response to this question, is due to the different times that the figures were extracted from the ATO information system and the fact that this is a peak processing period for tax-return related HECS payments and settlement of accounts.
HECS debtors and debt amounts in the Calwell electorate

entry.para: People currently enrolled in university study
People not currently enrolled in university study

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 17 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of the proposed time frame for the development of the Bayu-Undan gas field.

(2) Is he aware of the terms of the liquefied natural gas (LNG) export contracts and whether those contracts have been finalised; if so, when must those contracts be implemented in regard to product delivery.
(3) Is he aware that the agreed price for the sale of the LNG from Bayu-Undan to Japan is up to substantially higher than the price secured for the LNG recently contracted for sale to China.
(4) What is the anticipated value of production from Bayu-Undan.
(5) What share of Bayu-Undan proceeds will go to Australia and to East Timor, respectively.
(6) Have any of the partners in the Bayu-Undan field expressed concern to the Government about the completion of the legislative and regulatory processes necessary for the project to commence.
(7) Could delay into 2003 mean the loss of the Bayu-Undan project or provide the Japanese customers with an opportunity to negotiate a lower price for the product.

(8) If the operators are forced to re-negotiate the terms of the Bayu-Undan contract with the Japanese, what are the implications for Australian Government revenue and for the economy of the Northern Territory.

(9) Is he aware that Dr Geoffrey Raby from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade told the Joint Select Committee on Treaties on 14 October 2002 that it is the Governments view that it is in the national interest to risk the estimated $A2 billion in revenue from the Bayu-Undan in order to maximize the potential of all fields across the Joint Petroleum Development Area; if so, can he confirm that this is the Governments view and has the Government factored in the value of the associated infrastructure investment in Darwin.

(10) Have the partners in the Sunrise field venture indicated to him that progress has been made on an agreed development concept and timeline for the Sunrise project; if so, what is that plan and does it involve bringing the gas on-shore.

(11) Have the partners in the Sunrise field venture shared with him any information regarding progress on an agreed date for the commencement of the Sunrise project and for the flow of tax and other revenue from it to both Australia and East Timor.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Only what has been made public by Phillips, the operator of the project.
(4) On current estimates, Bayu-Undan contains petroleum worth about A$15 billion.
(5) 90% to East Timor and 10% to Australia.
(6) To my knowledge, these processes are continuing in the normal manner.
(7) I am not aware of any contractual details.
(8) See answer to 7 above.
(9) I am aware that Dr Raby appeared before the Committee but am not aware that he answered any proposition put to him in the terms referred to in your question.
(10) As explained previously, there is not, to my knowledge an agreed development concept.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) For the last year for which data is available, what was the cost to the Translation and Interpreter Service (TIS) of providing fee-free translation of identity and other approved documents for eligible new arrivals.
(2) Are eligible clients required to lodge any such documents with their local Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) outlet; if so, when did this arrangement commence.
(3) Are AMEP providers paid by his Department for receiving documents on the TIS's behalf; if so, what is the annual cost to the TIS.
(4) Was a tender process conducted for the provision of this service; if so, when was the tender awarded and when does the current contract cease; if not, why not.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The cost of providing the fee-free translation service in 2001-2002 was $689,627.
(2) Eligible clients are required to lodge requests for fee-free translations with their local AMEP outlet. The arrangement commenced on 30 April 2002.
(3) The AMEP providers are paid for receiving documents on TIS's behalf. The estimated cost for 2002-2003 is $340,000.

(4) An administrative decision was taken to include the fee-free translation collection service in the services provided under existing AMEP contracts. These contracts cease on 30 June 2003. The delivery of AMEP services for the five year period commencing on 1 July 2003, which includes the fee-free translation collection service, is currently the subject of a tender process.
